comments.commentBody: "Tweeting wasn't done in Plato's time."  Thanks for clarifying that.

Tweeting wasn't done in Plato's time. Ideas and names passed along by a curious route, from lips to ears to lips: "Let me introduce some countrymen of mine, I said; they are lovers of philosophy, and have heard that Antiphon was intimate with a certain Pythodorus, a friend of Zeno, and remembers a conversation which took place between Socrates, Zeno, and Parmenides many years ago, Pythodorus having often recited it to him"

Memorizers and reciters obviously want to pick their speakers carefully, and apparently did.

For writers, Plutarch's work is an acme of retweeting, passing along the records of the most notable and quotable ancients, comparing and contrasting. And in China, the same mechanism was a work, in the the parallel lives of Sima Xian, written a century earlier.

And, yes one line of Greek philosophy did move, in one line, to private excellence, the cult of stoicism. But I think rather than simply knocking Klout and calling for a a return to old time philosophy, we learn more by comparing views of reputation old and new. I thank Goldstein for moving the conversation along into this path.

I don't think chart says what everyone thinks means. Really the takeway is that when growth is too hot and inflationary then credit is tightened - when its not it is loosened. In the high growth period of 2004 to early 2008, China was fighting inflationary problems due to an overheated economy booming on exports - thus credit was kept very tight by govt set loan limits despite massive credit demand. When the crisis happaned in 2008 China took away credit restrictions and encouraged local govts to borrow for stimulus-like projects. Inflation came back modestly in 2011 and credit was slowed down. Now inflation now and credit is expanding.

I don't follow your logic: charter school teachers are underpaid, yet they are the same teachers who taught at public schools?  Are you saying public school teachers are so underpaid that they jump at the chance to have a job that underpays them less?

"The teachers who teach at charter schools are the very same teachers who used to teach at the local public schools..."

...well now we know why NY charter schools are largely . The failure of US K-12 education problem US is with the quality of the teachers more than anything else.

We have lower standards than nearly all developed nations and our teachers generally come from the BOTTOM TWO-THIRDS of their cohort while better-performing nations' teachers are from the TOP THIRD.

Stop making excuses and start cleaning house and measuring teacher capabilities and performance even more than those of students!

No justice, no pension!

The movement to replace public schools with pseudo-private schools in non-profit clothing is a part of the same movement to shrink government to a size that allows for drowning it in the bathtub.

Charter schools, on the whole, don't perform any better than public schools.

Charter schools, on the whole, pay teachers far less than they deserve. The teachers who teach at charter schools are the very same teachers who used to teach at the local public schools, only for a lot less. Charter schools don't have access to a better pool of teachers or administrators.

For those of us who have children with disabilities, charter schools are often discriminatory in their acceptance practices, leaving the public schools as a dumping ground to educate those among us with special needs.

Michelle Rhee and her ilk, along with ALEC, Heritage, Jeb Bush and his education organization, and other moneyed interests, have it as their mission to destroy two of the very things that have assured America many decades of prosperity: public schools and labor unions.

So no, Mayor de Blasio. Do not heed these calls. Not only did New York elect you, in part, so that you would implement the educational plans you ran on, but the rest of the nation is eagerly watching your progress. Yes, there will be distractions and obstacles along the way, including road blocks from other Democrats. Be strong. Don't waver. You will get the job done.

I agree, Paul, that 1954 was the greater upset. But I wouldn't cite the earlier group result between the two teams as the principal basis for that assessment.

W. Germany had easily won their 1st scheduled group game, against Turkey. Their coach, Sepp Herberger, figured they were likely to lose their 2nd game, against Hungary. So, as you know, he fielded a "reserve" squad for that game, with 5 players, including the keeper, who would •not• appear in the final. W.G. lost, as expected, but rested important players, and still earned a playoff match against Turkey — who W.G. again beat easily — for the group's 2nd spot in the knockout round.

W. Germany was also helped by the truly odd format of the tournament, which seems to have been devised by some guy who did not bother to run it by anyone with a lick of common sense. For example, each group had 2 seeded and 2 unseeded teams — but the seeded teams didn't play each other, and the unseeded teams didn't play each other.

But worse, in the knockout stage the 4 group-winning teams were placed in one bracket, and the 4 second-placed teams placed in the opposite bracket. So, to get to the final, Hungary had to win brutally tough matches against powerful Brazil and Uruguay, while W. Germany had relatively easy games against Yugoslavia and Austria.

Perhaps it's more to the point that in 1974 W. Germany were the reigning UEFA champions (winning in 1972). So, in '74 it was no •surprise• that they were a strong team.

— Brian

@Brian: One thing one can always say is that in World Cups concerning Germany, weird stuff happens:
1974 and 54, already dealt with. The 1966 Final in London, as mentioned by Louis with the Geoff Hurst "phantom goal" (revisited in the 2010 round of 16 when Frank Lampard's shot was *clearly* in and not given) in extra time of the final. In 1982, TWO weird and, um, unflattering things happened. First, there was the "arranged result" in the last group match between West Germany and Austria in Gijon that allowed the two teutonic countries to advance at the expense of Algeria, which had beaten West Germany. Paul, you are right, in any event, to call attention to W. Germany's deplorably violent play against Puskás in the Hungary-W. Germany group match. The video showing how Werner Liebrich hacked down Puskás can be see here:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?NR=1&v=DjohMNXakHs&feature=endscreen

starting about 10:43. It's basically a blunt kick to the ankles from behind, as Puskás is leaving Liebrich in the dust. There's nothing to redeem it, and it's disgraceful that Liebrich was allowed to remain in the game (or the tournament, for that matter).

That was about 30 minutes into the match; Puskás sustained a hairline fracture to his left ankle, and did not return to action till the final, two weeks later. Even then, he was not fully fit. Liebrich's thuggish play is shameful not only because it likely robbed Hungary of the championship; it deprived the world of the opportunity to see the best player in the world at the time, at his best, for almost all of the tournament.

— Brian

There's a curious parallel in the narratives of W. Germany's first two World Cup championships, 20 years apart in 1954 and 1974. In each case their opponent entered the championship match as the heavy favorite — and, indeed, each opponent, Hungary's "Golden Team" in 1954, led by their great star, Ferenc Puskás, and the Netherlands in 1974, led by •their• great star, Cruyff, are still revered as among the greatest teams ever to play the game.

And each match started in way that sure made it look like things were going to go according to "form". In 1954, Puskás and Zoltán Czibor scored quick goals, and Hungary was up 2-0 after 8 minutes. In 1974, as Mr Bell notes, the Netherlands went up a goal on Neeskens's PK only 90 seconds into the match — in which time W. Germany had not even touched the ball.

In both cases, spectators, seeing the favorites performing to expectations, must have thought, "The rout is on . . . ."

But strangely, in each case, the favorite failed to score again, and W. Germany came back to win in an astonishing upset. (Probably less stunning in 1974 than in 1954, but still, hardly the outcome most observers were expecting.) Each game remains fixed in memory, for a team that still stands as a romantic ideal, falling heartbreakingly short of the ultimate reward — and as a cornerstone in Germany's remarkable reputation for relentless determination, in finding a way to unlikely victories.

— Brian, State College

Opportunity in the United States has grown increasingly circumscribed, as indicated by persistent unemployment and underemployment. It is worth noting that the unemployment and underemployment numbers are understated: work as little as one hours weekly in your own trade or business, and you are counted as employed, even if you are losing money.

My best guess is that unemployment and underemployment are substantially under reported in the official figures and that many of us-- myself included-- are loath to report how difficult the last five to six years have been.

Unfortunately, our stubborn pride plays into the hands of Paul Ryan and his co-ideologists. What we really need is a dose of the famous line from the film Network: "I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it anymore."

I live in an area prone to tornados.  Trailer homes are very vulnerable but so are regular homes.   I was in a tornado a few years ago and was 'fortunate' that it was when I was picking up my kid from school-- a 1950s brick and cinderblock building.  Inside, we were so snug we had no sense of what was going on--was the tornado right out there or had it moved away?  We couldn't tell, that simple building was such a fortress.  When we did come out, the large old fallen trees and smashed roofs were a shock to us.  The solution is long overdue--trailer parks in states that are part of tornado alley should be legally required to build quickly accessible storm-proof shelters.

Upon further review, the part about the official end of a recession is not 100% correct:

"The Committee does not have a fixed definition of economic activity [in deciding whether a recession starts or ends]. It examines and compares the behavior of various measures of broad activity: real GDP measured on the product and income sides, economy-wide employment, and real income."

at: http://www.nber.org/cycles/recessions.html

But from what I've seen, they don't seem to rate the current unemployment rate (as opposed to the decline, if any) very heavily.

With regard to Spain, absolute level duhvcourse matters, not just growth. If your economy gratuitously cuts in half because you chose austerity, then it grows 1.5%, it's still about 48.5% smaller than it was, and could have been. That's a horror, not reason to claim victory.

If, as an investor, you lose 90% of your family's life savings, then you get a 1.5% return, do you say, Yea! See my strategy was right! Or do you say that if I had followed a smart strategy I'd be at 110% of where I started, not at 11.5% of where I started and claiming victory.

This also relates to our horrible definition of when a recession ends. We could be at 50% unemployment and 50% of the GDP before the depression, but if for two quarters we are up 0.1%, then it's, Yea! Depression and recession officially over! Even though half the economy is idle, and we're at 50% of our previous GDP.
